39243273.review:
ChromaGun é um jogo com uma atmosfera bem semelhante ao famoso Portal, composto principalmente de puzzles, onde se usa uma arma que atira tinta, tal tinta serve para atrair os "WorkerDroids", Droids com um formato esferico, que variam de ativo/ofensivo (Com espinhos) e inativos/inofensivos (sem espinhos), os mesmos são atraídos por cores semelhantes, ou seja, se ele é azul uma parede azul ira atraí-lo e etc...

No jogo há 8 cores:

As primárias: Azul, vermelho e amarelo
As secundárias ( Obtidas com a combinação das primárias): Roxo, verde e laranja
E as cores que não Atraem: Branco e castanho/preto ( resultante de misturar uma secundária com uma cor primária)

Em relação a dificuldade, ela aumenta com o decorrer do jogo, sempre vindo obstáculos e recursos que vão dificultando os puzzles.

36425734.review:
Of course I have to use the 'P'-word to describe this game. Test chambers, announcer guide narrator, things placed in a spot to open an exit, gun-tool that does stuff. If you need a break from the thousands and thousands of Portal levels out there but still want to run around and open up doors, definitely give ChromaGun a shot.

The premise is simple: Like-colors attract like-colors. Spray things the same color to attract them, or off-color to let them go. Open the exit door.

I'm halfway through now, and am enjoying the game a LOT. Color coding things is starting to get tougher, where I have to plan many steps ahead, programming the wall colors to lead a color somewhere when I'm somewhere else. Love it.

If there's a negative to the game so far, it's that I wish that I could undo a move. Not re-paint a thing ... but just step back in time to undo / un-paint and proceed again from there. Working on a level for 5 minutes, then realizing that I should have done something differently is ok, but having to restart the level from scratch is a bit of a bummer. Add to that the gun ... I wish that the color pipes roatated or changed to match the color ring. I keep thinking I'm spraying yellow (on top) when my ring is blue or red. That's not a big thing, just me wishing for a neat little improvement.

32625708.review:
ChromaGun - 8/10 - Bom

Quando recebi o jogo e vi o nome ChromaGun pensava que seria um jogo de ação  para atirar em todo mundo, mas não  o jogo não chega nem perto disso.

Resumidamente,  o jogo te dá uma pistola de cores que pinta alguns lugares de azul, vermelho, amarelo e as demais combinações entre elas.

O jogo é 90% estratégia e 10% ação e velocidade. É  um puzzle em primeira pessoa. A variedade de desafios é impressionante.

Chegar na saída é uma sensação de alívia sensacional.

O jogo ainda tem um modo de criação de novas fases :)

Dicas para iniciantes: 

1) As portas não se fecham se você  estiver logo abaixo delas.

2)  colorir uma bola durante  o movimento faz com que ela pare de se mover ( se não tiver nenhuma parede com a nova cor ao redor)

3) As bolas com espinho que ficam paradas começam a te perseguir se você atirar nelas, use isso  para ganhar tempo.

4) Pinte a parede com a cor da bola que te persegue e ela vai parar de te seguir.

5) Treine a mecânica de atração das paredes, isso vai salvar muitos replays no futuro.

Recebi esse jogo da  desenvolvedora e gostei bastante e indico para quem gosta de jogos de estratégia, mas  não tenho vontade de jogar novamente o modo história porque depois que você aprender as mecânicas de cada fase o processo fica mecânico.

Vale a pena, eu indico.

Obrigado por ler essa análise !

https://www.twitch.tv/faraquito

31479290.review:
This is a super fun first-person puzzle game in the vein of Portal, wherein you are a test subject for a pretty shady corporation with a sarcastic narrator. But besides the fact that they're both puzzle games, that's mostly where the similarities end. 

Mechanics:
You are equipped with a ChromaGun, which can shoot three colors: yellow, green, and blue. The colors can also be combined with each other to make magenta, green and orange. You use these colors to attract similarl colored hovering, sometimes murderous spheres to activate switches. Puzzles get more intricate with ones that require a lot of planning (since you can only add color, not subtract it, so level restarts are your only way to erase wrong colors), ones that need split second timing (there are a couple countdown events that require shaving off seconds to beat it before dying), ones that require you to reuse finite resources, ones where you have to complete a puzzle while being charged down by murderous "HelperBots", etc. 

Pros:
+There's a great deal of puzzle variety, as stated above, with timed challenges, take-your time color puzzles, don't waste your finite resources puzzles, open doors in the correct sequence or get stuck puzzles, etc.
+Good difficulty curve. Starts easy and gets progressively more difficult. Never seemed impossible, but there are definitely some thinkers.
+Great mechanic.
+Funny narration

Neutral:
~Length: I ran about 6 hours, including getting stuck and retrying a puzzle that I didn't realize I had actually solved, some idling, etc. I thought it felt like a pretty good length, but I could have definitely done with some more puzzles because it was actually really well done! Some people may feel it's too short but I personally don't feel cheated.

Cons:
-As stated above, narration was funny, but if you died a lot you'd get the same 3 or so dialogue snippits upon respawn, no matter how many times you died. It would have been nice if it recognized that you had already died several times in the same manner, so you don't need to be reminded not to touch the murderbots for the 6th time. (Like, I KNOW already.)
-There was one mechanic in the late-game that wasn't really introduced well. It didn't help that the effects of what you were doing weren't visible except from one weird angle, so I didn't know the piece I needed had been put into place until about a half hour later. There's only 1 other puzzle with this mechanic, and it is actually more obvious what is going on in the SECOND puzzle, which isn't a big help, honestly.

Overall: If you like good puzzlers with a fun mechanic, buy this game! 9/10. I'd definitely replay this game once I've forgotten most of the solutions.

28296061.review:
Ich habe ChromaGun nach einem kurzen Gespräch mit den Entwicklern auf der gamescom kostenlos erhalten.

Auf den ersten Blick erinnert das Spiel ein wenig an Portal, auch hier befinden wir uns in einer Testeinrichtung, halten eine Waffe in der Hand, die nicht zum Erschießen von Gegnern gedacht ist, und müssen Rätsel lösen um zum nächsten Raum zu gelangen.

Dabei ist ChromaGun keineswegs ein Portal-Klon, sondern schafft es, vollständig auf eigenen Beinen zu stehen. Die Spielmechanik ist in ihren Grundzügen so simpel, wie sie später im Spielverlauf auch fordern kann. Dabei ist das Spiel stets fair und es lässt sich immer nachvollziehen, woran man gerade gescheitert ist.

Technisch ist das Spiel gut gemacht, ich bin auf keine störenden Bugs gestoßen, die Grafik ist durchschnittlich, aber nicht schlecht.

Der einzige Kritikpunkt, den ich habe, ist der Umfang, nach etwa 3 Stunden hatte ich das Spiel durch. Hier wäre zum Beispiel ein Leveleditor mit Workshopintegration wünschenswert, sodass durch die Community immer wieder neue Levels erstellt werden können.

Ich kann ChromaGun aber in jedem Fall uneingeschränkt zum Kauf empfehlen.

26519913.review:
ChromaGun é um jogo de Quebra-Cabeça em Primeira Pessoa lançado em 16 de Fevereiro de 2016 pela Pixel Maniacs, desenvolvedora independente que é da cidade de Nuremberg na Alemanha. Apesar do jogo ser comparado principalmente à Portal, a única real coincidência é que aqui também estamos em uma fábrica fazendo testes de uma arma, mas a sua funcionalidade e a maneira como progredimos é totalmente diferente.

Iniciamos o jogo na porta da frente de uma das várias fábricas da ChromaTec, uma empresa cujas razões verdadeiras obviamente não são reveladas de início mas sabemos que eles estão testando essa nova arma, chamada simplesmente de "ChromaGun" para trabalhar em conjunto com o seu principal produto no mercado, os "WorkerDroids". Não é esclarecido também a função verdadeira desses dróides, mas se sabe que há 2 tipos: não-letal e letal.

O objetivo do jogo é simples: são 8 capítulos, divididos em 7 fases cada, sendo que o último são apenas 6. Cada fase, é um quebra-cabeça diferente que deve ser resolvido através da 3 cores da ChromaGun (Azul, Vermelho e Amarelo) que podem ser combinadas para fazer cores secundárias (Laranja, Roxo e Verde). Os dróides também tem essas cores e justamente ai que entra a mecânica do jogo: pintar paredes e o chão para fazer com que eles fiquem em cima dos controladores que abrem as portas e você avance para a próxima fase. Simples e direto assim.

As situações são das mais diversas possíveis e a única coisa que realmente incomoda é que as vezes o nível do desafio sobre abruptamente de uma hora para a outra e depois cai bastante novamente, sem nenhuma explicação aparente. Não é o suficiente para desistir do jogo, que além de ter essa grande variedade de quebra-cabeças, apesar de ter apenas 3 músicas disponíveis elas são muito bem produzidas e não enjoam mesmo depois de 6 horas de jogo.

Exatamente na metade do jogo, é esboçado um pouco de inserção de uma história um pouco mais trabalhada para entender um pouco mais sobre a ChromaTec e o personagem que estamos controlando, porém eles perderam essa oportunidade ao deixar isso passar batido nos capítulos subsequentes e se você espera por alguma conclusão pode ficar longe do jogo porque esse é daqueles finais que pode irritar se você procura por isso. 

O jogo foi lançado no Steam através do Steam Greenlight e está disponível para Windows e Mac por R$25,99 (U$9.99). O jogo trás 22 Conquistas para serem desbloqueadas, das quais nenhuma pede nada ridicularmente difícil ou que estrague a experiência tentando faze-las, é compatível com controles como o do Xbox One/360, tem modo de Realidade Virtual compatível com Oculus Rift, cartas colecionais e tem também legendas em português.

Honestamente, esse jogo foi a maior surpresa que joguei esse ano e acabei jogando por acaso, pois a empresa enviou uma chave de ativação do mesmo para o meu canal no YouTube e eu acabei gostando de verdade do jogo. Claro que o acabamento e o produto final não pode ser comparado à um título AAA como Portal, mas considero que o que foi feito aqui é muito bom se levando em conta a pequena equipe que produziu e caso esteja curioso para conhecer o jogo e esteja sem dinheiro há uma demonstração gratuita do jogo aqui no Steam

Не просто сочетании парочки цветов, а правильное обмозгованное передвижение шаров, не считая препятствии которые не дадут Вам так просто открыть следующий уровень. То есть звуки не имеют затухание в конце, но как я и сказал это НЕ ТАК ВАЖНО (ведь параллельно играющей с музыкой этого не заметно). Жаль нету полного русского перевода, хотя бы меню и субтитров)) Но если хотите принять вызов разработчиков можете смело проигнорировать все минусы, и показать что это будет для Вас слишком просто.

25486747.review:
I finally finished the entire game, and did a full walkthrough/let's play of this game on my channel.
Plus, I've earned all the achievements.

Anyways, I wish to thank all of the people who made this game, and with that, come with my honest opinion, so people can find this helpful, and as well, tell the people at Pixel Maniacs what I think.

Despite I got this for free from the company, I don't believe that should effect my opinion.
The price should be lowered, since I can't see it being worth 13 Euros, when you can complete the entire game within a short period of time, around the 10 Euros would be more fitting.

I truly enjoyed the concept, the idea of a puzzle game, which involves colors, was something that I haven't tried before, and that was truly something different, than what I normally play.
However, the game did seem quite short, and it has it's few moments that can be tricky. The only hard times, are when you're forced to make a wild guess. I believe that the game could've easily be longer, and a lot more challenging.

I must say, that I enjoyed the narrator and his evil voice, giving you some kind of hints now and then, but you barely heard from him later on in the game.

What I pretty much asked for, is more gameplay, and a greater challenge as you progress.
With all this said, the game is not bad at all, it's worth playing, but it should be for a smaller price then, since it is as short, as it is.

Big applause to Pixel Maniacs for this nice game. =)

Muy interesante, 
Al principio lo he visto por completo como un mod de portal, pero segun voy avanzando, puedo ver que tiene su propia personalidad, no deja ver demasiado de un posible lore, es mas, no creo que siquiera lo tenga, pero tampoco lo veo necesario, por ahora voy solo con 2 capitulos, y la forma en la que van avanzando los puzles me gusta, es muy muy progresivo, nada con lo que tengas que pensar mas de 3 minutos (A menos que, con palabras del juego "No hayas ido a preescolar")

El narrador tiene un humor curioso, aun no se si quiere ayudarnos, o vernos sufrir, pero cumple su funcion como forma de "tutorial"

El rendimiento, magnifico, aunque tampoco se podria pedir menos teniendo en cuenta su calidad
Con una GTX 960 + FX 8320 Se mantiene estable a 60, no he notado ninguna caida ni nada por el estilo

Quizás lo peor del juego, cosa que lo asemeja aun mas a Portal, son las pantallas de carga, pero al igual que con este, solo ocurren al cambiar de puzle, marcando el comienzo y el final del mismo de una forma bien definida, así que no lo pondré como algo negativo

Las mecanicas de mezclar colores y de que las piezas se situen en el centro geometrico de lo que pongas de su mismo color, da mucho mucho juego, por ahora, fantastico todo, muy recomendable.

25137285.review:
Was given this game by the CEO of the company, via Twitch messaging. Streamed it for about two hours, and got approximately halfway through the game (according to the in-game overhead dialogue).

Pros:
1: GREAT concept for a game!
2: Customizable controls (do it from the launcher, not from in-game!) I actually swapped Blue and Yellow (1 and 3), moved Zoom to F, and moved Sneak to LAlt.
3: Later puzzles REALLY make you think out the rooms you're in, and are no longer a cakewalk.
4: "Colorblind mode" uses symbols to show colors (didn't test it, not color-blind, but wanted to mention it DOES exist).

Cons:
1: First few levels are almost TOO easy (I know, tutorials, but I'm usually a quick study on controls and gameplay).
2: I'd personally swap where the blue and the yellow tubes are on the gun. On the left side, it shows Yellow/Red/Blue, but looking at the gun, it's colored Blue/Red/Yellow. Kept hitting blue while looking for yellow, and vice versa.
3: Zero help in-game if you get stuck. Either reset or die, over and over and over again. (No, I don't want the game spoon-fed to me, but I have the patience of a three-year old in a candy store.)

The overhead dialogue somewhat reminds me of the Portal series, although a bit less degrading towards you. (Good? Bad? I'll let you decide.)

In summary, it's not normally the type of game I'd play (I'm more of an RPG guy), but this game was actually fun. I don't feel like playing this game was a waste of my time, and I would recommend it to others.

25120939.review:
ChromaGun is an interesting game for me. And I personally have some mixed feelings about the whole package of the game. Let's start by breaking down my Pros and Cons.

So, for those of you deliberating whether to buy this game, I highly recommend it if you enjoy puzzle games such as Portal and others of that specific genre. It's a love letter to the game, containing a few hidden references for the player to find. 

The Pros:

The useage of colours to solve the puzzles is a fresh new take on the puzzle genre and provides a fun four hour experience. 

The game has eight chapters worth of chambers and almost every chapter has 7 stages tacked on, so you get a lot of gameplay for your money's worth. 

The Narrator is entertaining... when he's around.

The droids.


The Cons:

After a while the six colours you can make become a little boring. By chapter 6, I was desiring a new upgrade. Maybe an option that could revive rusted objects perhaps? 

The electric tiles and their hitboxes. If there's anything I disliked in this game, it's those electric tiles. I had my fair share of failures from them and they ruined my experience in the final room of the game as I kept getting shocked by them at the end due to the working droids pushing me into them (This is during an escape sequence where you really shouldn't die for maximum impact).

The lack of narration is some portions of the game. I couldn't help but feel like half of the chapters were just romps through the test chambers. We don't have as much interaction with the Narrator as I would have liked and I just couldn't care for the character when he talked. Sometimes I forgot he was there.

The end of Chapter 4. Because a few floors in to chapter 5 we completly ignore what had happened like it had never taken place.


Overall, I'd give this game a solid 7/10 with a recommendation to Buy it! The game works, caters to all audiences and is an easy fix for those with Portal withdrawel symptoms. But keep in mind the game doesn't have much of a story and sweeps any narrative portions under the rug fairly quickly.

Игра ChromaGun является головоломкой с видом от первого лица. 
Сюжет прост. Используя оружие стреляющее цветными зарядами, которые окрашивают стены и/или дроидов, пробиться к выходу на следующий этаж. В игре 8 глав по 5-9 этажей. Начинается игра с очень простых заданий, которые постепенно усложняются. Затем наступает момент, когда необходимо серьезно включать мозг. Любое неверное действие приводит к невозможности прохождения этажа и требуется рестарт.

25087808.review:
Got that itch for Portal, but can't be bothered to replay Portal(2) for the umpteenth time? Good, time to stop thinking with Portals and remember how subtractive color addition works!

Chromagun is a first Person Puzzler, and took a lot of inspiration from Portal. The playtime was roughly around 4 hours for me as someone who has played both Portal and Portal 2. There is a "Speedrun" mode implemented as well, so if you're into that.. There's more play time to be had, to really get those best times down.

Graphics and sound are not bad by any means, but they won't be Portal level, of course. They work for the game though since the focus is on the puzzles in the whole game. Speaking about the puzzles, I felt like there were some slight problems in terms of Flow from time to time. I've gotten through some of the apparently more difficult levels with ease, only to be hit i nthe face with a level that is way easier than I anticipated in which I will try to overengineer the solution as much as possible. Then again, that could be a personal quirk as well.

So, this game is about colours, you say, but what about the folks who can't see all the rainbow-y greatness that is this game? Fret not, for this game actually has a pretty snazzy Colourblind mode, overlaying all coloured surfaces with marks that also combine properly when mixing colours.

The ending was somewhat antclimactic in retrospect and is the biggest negative point I have. I mean, the story isn't anything to write hme about either, but serves its purpose - But that ending just felt like a slap in the face compared to Portal. I don't want to spoil too much, but a timed level doesn't make for the best finale, in my opinion.

Would I recommend the game and why/why not?
I'd recommend the game. If you like Portal and want a game for a rainy day/slow night - This is right up your alley. Into speedrunning and want to try something different? Give Chromagun a shot.

Are you looking for a 100hr+ game for $5 max? Go away, deinstall steam and take a looooong walk.

25052277.review:
This game was not too bad, but I wanted to give a negative review to warn about a couple of things people should know. (I am running on Linux):

- You can't reconfigure the key assignments. For 99% of you that's not a problem. For the few that don't use the standard keys it can be a deal breaker.

- You can't tweak graphics advanced. That's fine, I might not allow it if I wrote a game myself (to avoid the support headache). But you can't enable frame sync and my graphics have distracting shearing and other distortions as a result.

- The play concept seems fun, but the graphics quality themselves is poor and, in spite of what I read in other reviews, I thought the writing for the voice over was a painfully not-funny amateur attempt at Portal 2 like humor. I couldn't judge how good the voice itself was because the material was so bad that nothing could have saved it.

- You'll notice I don't have much play time. The first time a robot killed me I crashed and dropped out of the program. Along with the other issues it wasn't worth it to me to try again and risk crashing all the time. I just bailed and wrote this review mostly to warn people about the keys.

25027516.review:
I hate comparing games to other games in a review, but it's almost unavoidable in the first-person puzzle-platform genre, since Portal has basically been the gold standard since 2007. I feel that ChromaGun captures the elements that made Portal great (excellent gameplay, humor, puzzles, progressive addition of new mechanics) without feeling like a clone or a rip-off. It's simple, fun, challenging, and full of color. And you get to shoot robots with paint. Hard to beat that combination.

The only bad thing I have to say is that I think the price is high for the amount of content (playing casually, I completed the game in about 4 hours). That said, I've read rumors (and the game's narrator drops a couple of hints) that there may be more content coming (possibly a level editor?) in the future. If that's the case, then I retract my complaint about the price. I'd love to see the developers build more upon the concepts they've established so far.

(I just have one question for the devs: Why are you able to jump? You literally never need to use it, and you only get about two inches off the ground anyway. :) )

25015144.review:
Great game and lots of fun. Chill soundtrack, appealing artsyle. For experienced puzzle gamers the first few chapters might be a little bit easy, but the later levels get tougher. The mechanics of this game allow for some great puzzles with clever, out-of-the-box solutions that often times made me smile, when I figured them out. Despite being short, ChromaGun is definitely well worth it's price and the developers promised to add a level editor with an upcoming patch, allowing user-generated levels adding to the game's content. (At least that's what I've been told at Gamescom)

Furthermore it is worth mentioning all the obvious little things in the game hinting at the fact that the Portal series heavily inspired ChromaGun. I mean, they had the freaking Portal Cake(TM) at their booth at Gamescom and any Portal player will feel at home upon starting up a new game.

If you like puzzle games. Buy this.
If you like Portal. Buy this.
If you like great Indie games. Buy this.

Enjoy.

24931524.review:
[h1] İnceleme + Video [/h1]
Herkese merhaba. Bu videomuzda ChromaGun isimli oyunu beraber inceleyeceğiz. ChromaGun birincil şahıs bakış açısıyla oynanan bir puzzle oyunu. Oyunda amacımız droid denilen yuvarlak uçan nesneleri doğru konumlara getirerek yolumuza devam etmek ve içinde bulunduğumuz odadan diğer bir odaya geçmek. Henüz oyunun 2 bölümünü tamamlamamıza rağmen kafamızda oyuna dair birçok artı ve eksi özellik yer etti. Artılara değinmemiz gerekirse, bize göre oyunun en büyük artısı çözdüğünüz bir puzzle'ın diğer bir puzzle ile doğrudan ilişkisinin bulunması. Örneğin bir oda zincirindesiniz ve birbine farklı konumlardan bağlı 4 oda var. İlk odada kullandığınız droidi geri dönüp yanınıza getirerek son puzzle'ı çözmeniz gerekebiliyor. Oyun aynı zamanda sizi boşa uğraştırmak için elinden geleni yapıyor. Tamamen gereksiz ve o puzzle'da zerre kadar işinize yaramayacak bir ton obje koyarak sizin puzzle'ı nasıl çözeceğinizi anlamamanıza sebep oluyor.Oyunda bize bir de dış ses eşlik ediyor. Sesin esprili bir şekilde verdiği talimatlar ve ipuçlarıyla oyunu anlıyoruz. Kat geçişlerinde odaya girmeden önce sizi bir ekran karşılıyor ve size oyun içi mekanik vb konularla ilgili bilgiler veriyor. Bu da gözünüzden kaçan bir mekanik olma ihtimalini minimuma indiriyor. Son olarak oyunun yapımcılarının eklediği ufak gibi görünen ama çok büyük önem taşıyan bir özellikten bahsedelim. Oyuna renk körü modu eklenmiş ve bu mod sayesinde herbir rengin kendine özel bir sembolü var ve renk körleri oyunu renkler yerine bu sembollerle oynuyor. Oyunun eksilerine değinmemiz gerekirse oyunun puzzle'larını çözerken yanlış bir işlem yaptığınızda geri alamıyor ya da düzeltemiyorsunuz. Bu belki de oyunu daha zor bir hale getirmek için yapılmış bir eylem olabilir fakat hem bir süre sonra oyun şevkini kırıyor hem de boş yere vakit kaybetmemize sebep oluyor. Yanlış bir işlem yaptığınızda geri dönmek isterseniz son kontrol noktasından başlamak zorunda kalıyorsunuz. Oyunda kontrollere bakmamızı veya değiştirmemizi sağlayan bir ayarlar menüsü yok. Bu da benim aramış olduğum fakat bulamadığım bir unsur. Son olarak oyunun en büyük eksisi de tamamıyla Portal'ı anımsatan bir oyun olması. Grafikleri ve chroma silahı bize Portal'ı anımsattı. Bize yeni bir oyun oynuyormuş hissiyatından ziyade Portal serisinin yeni bir oyununu oynuyormuş hissiyatını verdi. Videomuza son vermeden önce oyunun yapımcıları olan PixelManiacs'ın diğer oyunlarına göz atmak için sağdaki linke ChromaGun'ın steam sayfasını görüntülemek için soldaki linke tıklayabilirsiniz. Kendinize iyi bakın. Hoşçakalın.

24927033.review:
This game is hilarious fun! With a snarky, cynical narrator with the stylings of GLaDoS and a similar voice to the Narrator from The Stanley Parable, this game is entertaining from the start!
 The puzzles are heavily inspired by Portal, using little WorkerBots to be attracted by coloured walls and hover over spots that open doors and such. It's bloody fun, and nothing could ruin this game! 
The only things I have to point out is how seemingly bland the test rooms are in chapters 1-2, and also the distinct lack of the Narrator after the tutorial. 
Besides that, this game is wonderful! I'd heartily recommend it to anyone looking for a great puzzle game!
(Also, the Devs are very kind people. Do not be afraid to approach them with constructive criticism!)

24761198.review:
[h1] Buen juego de puzzles de los alemanes Pixel Maniacs [/h1]

Juego de puzzles con una estética muy similar a Portal pero con mecánicas diferentes, basadas en la gama cromática y la mezcla de colores, muy recomendable para los que les guste este tipo de juegos. Tiene una especie de narrador que nos va contando un poco la "historia" del juego y que hacemos ahí probando la "pistola" de colores. Los puzzles empiezan siendo muy sencillos para que vayamos acostumbrándonos a las mecánicas jugables y van subiendo la dificultad de manera progresiva, algunos son realmente complicados.

Dura aproximadamente unas 5 horas, quizá un poco escaso para los 13 euros que vale, pero se puede conseguir en las rebajas de steam por unos 5 euros.

En cuanto a gráficos cumple de sobra, no destaca especialmente pero en lo que he podido probar no he encontrado ni bugs, ni falllos de ningún tipo. El sonido también cumple con unas buenas melodías que amenizan las partidas sin molestar ni resultar repetitivas en ningún momento. 24717044.review:
[h1]A First Person Adventure Puzzle Game[/h1]
https://youtu.be/CeehaaflX2Y
+ Many similarities to Portal. You are in a test lab as a random participant chosen to test some new military grade color morphing gun.  
+ A pretty comical narrator talking through intercom (I think) who watches and follows you throughout the game through various cameras and makes fun of you from time to time. 
+ The gameplay is pretty fun and unique. You mainly go through a series of rooms which each have a puzzle to solve. The main mechanic involves painting hovering balls or "droids" and then painting a wall the same color which will attract the droid to the wall...generally to press a switch to open a door of some sort. Later you being to combine colors in every increasingly difficult puzzle challenges.
+ Visually the game very nice with a very clean test-lab asethetic. 
+ The puzzles gradually increase in difficulty and can be quite challenging to solve....just be sure to bring a color wheel if you've never taken an art class ;)

- I wish the narrator was "more involved". I wish he would have spoke more often, and it would have been nice if he provided some hints when you got stuck. He's honestly the most charming part about the game, and really helps push the player forward although he's a bit absent through many parts.
- The environment / puzzles got a bit repetitive for me after a short while. It felt like a never-ending labryinth, and I kept asking myself "will I ever get out of here?" It really needed some more events to change up the pace and scenery.

24698295.review:
As a small youtuber who will play just about anything, I was quite pleased to have gotten this in my inbox about a week ago. I expected a simple puzzle game, but the reality was far better than I expected. It's not the prettiest game on the block, but the really smart color puzzles that truly make you think out your order of operations won me over. There were a few rooms that took me a half dozen tries or more to get through. Remembering you can turn things brown to make them inert comes into play a few times as well. Then theres a few parts where you're chased by brown workerdroids... fun times. The narration is amusing, aiming to be in the vein of Portal 2, and isn't too obtrusive. I only had a couple times when I would be forced to restart a room and there would be a narration replayed at me. 

My main quibble is that there isn't a way to unpaint a wall after you've messed up. Thankfully, the rooms that this can occur are generally pretty short and you've got all the time in the world - for the most part - to figure them out. A quick restart and you can try again.

I had a lot of fun with this one. Check it out.

24609468.review:
[b][u]See written review below[/u][/b] or watch it here: https://youtu.be/kfuTC9c-GG4
[h1]THIS IS A MIXED REVIEW! TL;DR: SKIP TO CONCLUSION![/h1]

ChromaGun is a first person puzzle game where you are a test subject that uses colours to solve your way through the ChromaTec testing chambers.

When I first started playing, I got a Portal vibe from the game, probably because of the testing facility theme, and being immediately armed with a ChromaGun, but that’s about where the similarities between the two games end. Your main objective throughout the game is to open the exit door and move on to the next room, and there isn’t much of a story.

So, you’re in this testing facility, and your gun shoots three primary colours (red, yellow, and blue), and you can also mix colours to form secondary colours orange, green, and violet. You use your ChromaGun to shoot colours onto walls, droids and sometimes on the ground, in order to attract nearby droids of the same colour. By positioning them correctly, you’ll get the doors to open. 

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list][*]graphics are simple, but decent (similar to Q.U.B.E. with all the white-walled rooms)
[*]sound effects and music are good
[*]voice acting for the narrative is done well, and it's amusing at times (similar to Quantum Conundrum with far less dialog)
[*]interesting puzzle mechanics with mixing colours is straightforward, but still enjoyable if you aren’t looking for too much of a challenge
[*]speedrun mode available[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list][*]puzzles are too easy for those looking for a challenge, which leads to the game being a bit short (some more complex levels or larger rooms where not everything was on the same floor could’ve been neat)
[*]the colour brown doesn’t work to attract the brown droids, like the other colours - it seems that it’s intended, but I don’t quite understand the reasoning behind it, since there's no way to undo colours once you shoot them, so if you accidentally turn things brown you might have to restart the level (it’s not a big deal, but still a minor nuisance)
[*]small annoyance with the loading screen between levels being before you even get to the door where you have to wait anyway; could also do without the special loading screen
[*]some of the voice lines get repeated when you restart the level, which is fine for the most part, as long as you don’t restart too frequently[/list]

The game starts off very easy, and it gets slightly more challenging as it progresses, but only a small handful of puzzles near the very end actually made me have to stop and think about what to do. Even then though, it was more of me trying to get the droids in the just right spot by colour changing at the right time, rather than actually having to figure the puzzles out. There are some levels that are timed, where you will burn to death if you mess up, and normally, I’m not usually a big fan of timed events, but these levels easy as well, and just took a couple attempts to solve.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
The game took me about 3 hours to complete, and I don’t feel the need to replay it, but there is a speedrun mode available for those who are interested. The gameplay is smooth, and I did enjoy the puzzles even though most of them were pretty easy, but I would have really liked to have had some flexibility in how you can go about solving puzzles, or even just more complex level design to make the game more challenging. If you’re interested in some puzzle gameplay with simple mechanics, you will probably enjoy ChromaGun, but keep in mind that it is a short game, and easier than games like Q.U.B.E. or Portal.

If you like my reviews, please feel free to join my Steam group, and follow my curations [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AzralynnReviews#curation]here.[/url]
You can also view this review on my website [url=http://www.azralynn.com/chromagun-quick-game-review/]here.[/url]

24546549.review:
[h1]Взрываем мозг изнутри![/h1]

   Игры-головоломки может и не идут на первых местах в игровых чартах, но всегда занимают отдельное место среди всех остальных игр. По пальцам можно пересчитать интересные и познавательные проекты. И с годами почти ничего не меняется. Приятно, что в 2016 году в ряды увлекательных, в меру сложных и необычных игр прибавилась ещё одна - "[b]"Chroma Gun"[/b]".
   Хотя весь сценарий укладывается в пару фраз, да и присутствует скорее для антуража, в самой игре полностью забываешь о чём-либо, но целиком погружаешься в процесс решения различных головоломок. Первые 10 минут вообще не испытываешь какой-то сложности и на минуту посещает мысль о скором прохождении всей игры, но уже через пару уровней неожиданно сталкиваешься с ситуацией из которой не можешь выйти. Вроде бы лёгкая задача превращается в затруднение, а ещё через минут 10 она тебя начинает уже и раздражать. Однако именно такими моментами, которые ставят игрока в тупик должна и может похвалиться наша сегодняшняя героиня.
   Спустя несколько следующих уровней, погрузившись в происходящее и освоившись с принципами и логикой игры ты уже начинаешь постепенно, но безвозвратно менять своё мнение с прохладного до восторженного. Именно так произошло и со мной. В начале я проявил интерес к игре, затем она меня несколько озадачила и начала даже напрягать своей неочевидностью, но после успешного завершения нескольких уровней и появления чувства преподнятости интеллекта над машиной ))) моё мнения окончательно перешло в категорию восхищения. 
   Эта игра взрывает твой мозг изнутри и ты этому радуешься! Красочная головоломка от [url=http://pixel-maniacs.com][b]PixelManiacs[/b][/url] обязательно понравится всем любителям сложностей. И эта игра предоставит вам массу возможностей убедиться в собственном бессилии в решении очередной задачи... или покажет Твой исключительный интеллект)))

Искренне рекомендую всем! А если хотите увидеть игровой процесс и услышать мои комментарии и мнение об игре, тогда смотрите [url=https://youtu.be/1EwToWw__vQ][b]Стрим-прохождение "Chroma Gun"[/b][/url]

https://youtu.be/1EwToWw__vQ

И большая благодарность, Крису из [b]Pixel Maniacs[/b] за возможность познакомиться с этой игрой-головоломкой.

Many thanks to Chris from [b]Pixel Maniacs[/b] for this game! I was very surprised given support and the opportunity to get to know your game "ChromaGun".

С уважением, Дмитрий Харитонов / Dinlog / 27 июля 2016 г.

24458389.review:
Titulů, které staví na podobných principech jako Portal najdeme hromadu. Ne všechny ovšem oplývají originálním nápadem. ChromaGun mezi takové naštěstí nepatří. Barvy, okolo kterých se vše točí jsou podle mého názoru nadmíru originální.

Hra, alespoň v počátečních puzzlech, používá naprosto jednoduchý koncept. Máte zbraň, která dokáže střílet barevné kuličky a obarvovat jednotlivé segmenty stěn místnosti. Pak roboty, kteří jsou podle svých barev přitahováni ke stěnám stejné barvy a nakonec tlačítka na zemi, které potřebujete pomocí robotů udržet stisknuté. Zní to jednoduše? Tak to zkuste!
Ale nejdříve si připočtěte to, že ze základních třech barev můžete vytvořit kombinacemi další odstíny a každé pole stěny, nebo robot lze obarvit pouze dvakrát. Jednou základní barvou, třeba červenou, podruhé přidáním další barvy, například modré pro vznik fialové. Po třetím pokusu o přebarvení pole "zrezne" a vy už neuděláte nic. Pak následuje restart levelu.

Prvních pár minut hry se vám opravdu může zdát, že je až příliš jednoduchá, ale to byl Portal taky. Začne ukrutně přituhovat a už po cca deseti minutách vás hra začne nutit pořádně si postup promýšlet.

Zatím jsem nedosáhl vyšších levelů, takže opravdové hardcore levely posoudím až dodatečně, ale musím říct, že na procvičování logického uvažování je hra skvělá.
Navíc plně podporuje VR, konkrétně Oculus Rift, ale myslím, že ji rozjedete i na HTC Vive. S VR systémem bude zážitek určitě ještě mnohem lepší.

Grafika je jednoduchá, ale pro hru tohoto typu naprosto nepodstatná věc. Ovšem design není nikterak krásný, jako třeba v Portalu 2. Prostě je to tuctové, ale vás to stejně zajímat nebude. 
Ve hrách tohoto typu je o poznání důležitější hudba a ta je podle mého názoru minimálně dobrá a dá se v klidu poslouchat.
Zvuky také nejsou špatné, jen mě trochu rušil hlas vypravěče, i když barvou hlasu zní skvěle, nějak mi do hry nesedí. Prostě zase vzpomínám na Portal, kde je to dokonalé.

Hra navíc obsahuje i Speedrun režim, kdy se můžete pokusit pokořit protihráče z celého světa. Ve speciálním režimu hra obsahuje počítadlo času, za který se vám podaří hru zdolat. Počítadlo je nastaveno přesně pro potřeby speedrunu a tak se zastavuje při loadingu a počítá opravdu jen při hře. To zajistí, aby byly výsledky na všech počítačích přesné.

Hra podle mě bezproblému poběží i na starších strojích a myslím, že i s VR si poradí průměrné VR Ready sestavy.

Moje hodnocení: 85/100

+skvělý nápad
+přituhující obzížnost puzzlů
+jednoduchá hratelnost, každý zvládne během minuty a to včetně nehráčů
+dobrá hudba
+podpora VR (NETESTOVÁNO)
+speedrun režim

-nehezká grafika
-vadí mi vypravěč, i když se snaží vtipkovat po vzoru Portalu
-obrazovky s nápovědami před jednotlivými levely mají tak nízké rozlišení, že prakticky není možné přečíst jejich nápovědu

24334759.review:
Chromagun is a first person puzzler game similar to many such games available on Steam like Portal series, Magnetic: Cage close, Q.U.B.E, etc. You have a paint gun which you have to shoot at droids and walls and combining these two actions you’ll have to trigger switches which open doors to the next level.

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]

The graphics are run of the mill average. Nothing too fancy, the levels are mostly white with little color. This makes sense because the whole game is about coloring the wall panels and the puzzles are based on coloring them correctly, so a white background is the ideal in this case. There aren’t too many graphics options in the game. The game is locked at 60 FPS but I noticed no slowdowns or dips in FPS. The game also features colorblind mode so that’s always a positive.

[h1]Sound:[/h1]

The game has very slow and relaxing music. The sound effects can be a bit annoying though. The narration is very well done in this game. I was quite impressed with the narrator. It has funny humor as narration just like Portal.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

Your main Chromagun can shoot paint in 3 colors, yellow, blue and red. You can combine these colors to make purple, green and orange i.e. yellow and red will make orange etc. You have to go through bunch of tests and unlock doors to open new levels. To open doors there are switches in each level. There can be more than one switch and more than one door as well. The switches correspond to their respective doors and this is represented by a wire on the ground which is color coded. So if you see a purple wire going out from a switch you just follow it and it’ll tell you which door this switch will open.

To activate switches you have to get these droids to move on top of them. You can paint the droids and certain types of wall panels. The droid will be attracted to the same colored wall panel and if there are 2 or more of the same color wall panels, the droid will stay in the middle of these. E.G if there are 5 panels of blue colors right next to each other, the blue painted droid will go to the wall and stand in front of the 3rd blue wall panel. If the number is even, the droid will stay in-between the 3rd and 4th panel. 

There are 2 types of droids, normal ones and spiked ones. The normal ones don’t move unless you paint a wall near them with the same color they are. The spiked ones however, once you paint them, they get triggered and they follow you around and hurt you and eventually kill you. This can be stopped by luring them next to the wall that is same color as these droids. So, you have to make use of this to solve puzzles. 

A short gameplay video can be found below:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=724989891

[b][u]Graphics:6/10[/u][/b]
[b][u]Sound:7/10[/u][/b]
[b][u]Gameplay:7/10[/u][/b]
[b][u]Overall:7/10[/u][/b]

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]

If you’re into first person puzzle games similar to Portal, Q.U.B.E, Magnetic: Cage closed etc. then this game is right up your alley. It’s got enough content for its price and in my opinion and should keep you entertained for 4-5 hours easily. If you think that’s not enough you can always wait for the next big sale and pick it up. The game has some awesome narration as well which can be entertaining.

24162824.review:
First, the company provided a copy to me for review, yes I checked the little box, but just to be sure everyone knows upfront! :D

So now lets take a look at the game, keep in mind there is a backstory to the game and I'll try to reduce spoilers, but you have been warned ;)

→ Game Overview
Portal-esk in concept, where your character volunteered for a research program related to a new paint technology, and over the course of the story, the situation for your character goes from bad to worse.  As you advance in the game, the scenarios become progressively more challengeing, requiring you build on your understanding of the gameplay mechanics and to explore new ways of doing the same things, unlocking the door to the next stage.

→Major Features
-Single Player
-Leaderboards (for speed running)
-VR Support (Oculus Rift™ DK2)

→Gameplay
As a 3d interactive puzzle game, it has moments of high excitement followed by periods of calm where you can take your time to figure out how to progress.  The use of primary colors throughout the game, and being a core mechanic, feels simple at first, but actually becomes challenging in ensuring you are applying those colors correctly while completing the puzzle.  This aspect might frustrate some players looking for a straight forward 'run and gun' experience, but for the puzzle lovers, you might really enjoy this.

→Pros
-Fun gameplay
-Easy to pick up basic mechanics
-Leaderboards for competing with other players
-Challenging Puzzles
-Dev Team is very interested in player experience

→Cons
-Some elements could be better explained (looking at you 'paint reflecting' walls)
-Short overall game (speed runners are completing it in ~2 hours)
-Limited replay ability outside of improving speed-run times/score/achievement hunting

→Summary
Overall, while experienced 'portal runners' might find the game on the easy to moderate side early on, some of the later puzzles may make you stop and rethink your strategy a few times, or in some cases even force you to restart the level.  This, to me, makes it worth your time if you're into action style puzzle games, like games that try different takes on the 'portal' style of game, or just have that twisted bit within you that enjoys a fun game that tries to constantly kill you!

23953447.review:
[Product received for free]

Quick review: Mostly positive

Good stuff / General information:
- Took me about 3hr 15m to finish the first time
- Clever puzzles involving getting objects to move to switches by attracting them with matching colors. It gets more complicated because you can paint the objects as well and not "unpaint" them. Also, mixing colors and objects with different behaviors.
- Heavy Portal inspiration, and not just because it's a first person puzzle game. It's in a testing facility and there's a funny narrator who doesn't have your best interest in mind.
- Has a speedrun mode, so that's nice.
- Good design that mostly teaches by showing and letting you discover for yourself rather than straight up telling you what to do.
- Multiple solutions sometimes.
- Decent music, though you probably won't notice it usually.

Less good stuff:
- There were probably only two puzzles that I felt were unfair because of key elements being obscured by walls/doors, requiring you to guess part of the solution. Maybe I was missing something, but I doubt it. 
- Making a mistake often required that you restart the entire level, but that doesn't usually turn out to be so bad since you can redo it quickly once you know the solution.

My full playthrough is up here, but it'll spoil puzzles for you, so watch at your own risk: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sYwTnsks0lA

23762023.review:
I thoroughly enjoyed Chroma Gun, and I suspect anyone who likes first person puzzlers as much as me will find similar enjoyment. However it wasn’t a flawless experience.
[b]The Good[/b]
[list]
	[*]Solving puzzles more often than not felt satisfying.

	[*]The puzzle design for the most part was well done and left me impressed.
[/list]
[b]The Adequate[/b]
[list]
	[*]The narrative is what you’d expect, from a disembodied GlaDOS-esque narrator. While I found a moment here and there humorous, the story was mostly benign merely acting as a vehicle for the puzzles. 
[/list]
[b]The Bad[/b]
[list]
	[*]There were a few fast paced sequences that to me were more frustrating than fun or exciting; as well as a dark, flashlight section that was a bit straining on the eyes (for me anyway).
	
	[*]There are no colorblind options from what I could see. So if this is something that might affect you, it would be a good idea to watch some videos and see how well you can distinguish between the colors.
[/list]
All and all I’m glad I made this purchase. I should mention that I bought this game at a sale price of $5.84 as opposed to the normal price of $12.99. That being said I think I would have still been satisfied.

My initial reaction to the game was surprised by just how heavily it borrowed from Portal. While i understand the developers used it for inspiration i felt it was just too much similar. From the entire style of the voice over character, to the turret like drones, white featureless walls, cameras that move when shot, level transitions and fire chasing you as they destroy the facility.

Then when i got to the ending of the game and realised i had only been playing for 2 and a half hours i checked the price tag on steam and was a bit disappointed that a $13 USD game wasnt even 3 hours long. By steams refund ToS people could completely buy, play, finish and then some with the game and still easily refund it, without any issue.

The AI on the droids and movement of the character also felt very clunky at times where the momentum of the character was very ice skaterish and the droids movement felt very jagged and box like.

This game is alright as a premise, but I think it needed a lot more work before asking for $10+. The controls are pretty clunky, the rooms are all bland and white, and overall it feels like the Alpha/Protoptype of a game that should've had more development put into it. It also tried way too hard to copy Portal's formula; You are given a puzzle-gun to solve puzzles in white rooms while a narrator watches and comments on your actions, all while the facility goes to shit as you are testing in it. The puzzles themselves are fairly simple, which may be a consequence of the simplistic premise that floating robots are attracted to color panels that match their own color.

Normally I really love puzzle games, but I just can't recommend this one as is. It feels like an awkward, free mod to a better puzzle game. I just found it far too tedious and I rarely found any satisfaction in solving a puzzle.

23377585.review:
Okay, my first review, but here we go:

Choma Gun is a 1st-Person Puzzle Shooter, whith Colors-Pellets instead of Lead-Bullets, dark Humor instead of dark Colors and Death instead of... forget it ^^'
There are 26 Levels/Sections, divided in 8 Chapters, which have different tasks realized with a few, but cleverly used game-play mechanics, such as 

"lazy" bots (will only move when they are colored like a  wall in their close vicinity),
"stalking" bots (which want to help you, but can be a real pain in the ass),
walls (usually white, but sometimes pre-colored)
"Fences" (which prevent you from coloring bots or walls)
and several more.

The graphics are, while not as realistic as some other games, as good as needed that there are no misunderstandings in the puzzles, so you can see the difference between a "stalking" bot and a normal, lazy one.
Since I have a really weak machine (384 Cuda-Cores, DDR3-Ram) I had several times lags when there was a bit more happening on the screen, but it wasn't impossible to solve the puzzle in those levels.

There are not many soundtracks, but they work well in the game, since you'll think hard most of the time, so the soundtrack does not disturb your thoughts. There is one person whom you'll hear often enough, he explains some mechanics, but most of the time he'll annoy you with some information that you are not good enough. It'll ceasy soon enough, but until then you'll be annoyed

While my first playthrough was roughly 2 Hours, it is possible to finish the game in less that 40 Minutes, when you have memorized it at least once. The puzzles were sometimes challenging, sometimes eazy and sometimes you had to know that the solution was easier than anticipated

There are achievements, some tend to annoy a little bit (after every chapter is one achievement), others are well designed, so you have to search, think and act a little bit different to unlock 'em all.

I personally recommend everyone this game, that likes to think or wants to experience a puzzle-game that is easy to understand, but not so easy to master.

23004070.review:
Si toi aussi tu ronges ton frein en attendant [i]Portal 3[/i] (il n'est pas interdit de rêver, que je sache...), voici qui devrait t'occuper trois ou quatre heures. Encore que, pour être tout à fait honnête, [b][i]Chromagun[/i][/b] n'arrive pas à la cheville de son modèle. Ce qui n'en fait pas pour autant un mauvais jeu, bien au contraire ! Disons juste que les similitudes sont ni nombreuses que le terme "portal-like" ne pourrait être plus approprié pour le qualifier. Or, trop s'approcher d'un [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198164382571/recommended/400][i][b]Portal[/b][/i][/url], c'est s'exposer à la comparaison...

Commençons par l'histoire : vous vous trouvez dans un ascenceur, qui s'enfonce dans le complexe scientifique aseptisé d'une entreprise nommeé Chromatec. Depuis les haut-parleurs, une voix vous accueille, puis, après deux ou trois vannes, vous guide jusqu'aux premières salles de test. Bien entendu, dans la foulée, on vous refourgue une arme expérimentale qui permet de peindre certaines surfaces en jaune, en bleu ou en rouge ; avec chacune des combinaisons que cela implique. Autant vous dire que pour l'originalité, il faudra repasser.

Heureusement, le gameplay est intéressant, même si les habitués du genre ne feront des énigmes qu'une seule bouchée. Pour l'essentiel, le concept de [b][i]Chromagun[/i][/b] est basé sur l'attraction. Dans ces salles de test, vous rencontrerez des droïdes (éteints, en veille ou actifs) que vous pourrez peindre, du moins la plupart du temps. Un droïde vert sera ainsi attiré par des murs verts, le but étant de les disposer sur les interrupteurs qui commandent à l'ouverture des portes. Au fil de la progression s'y greffent quelques mécaniques supplémentaires : des dalles électrifiées, des écrans, par exemple.

En somme, [b][i]Chromagun[/i][/b] est un bon jeu, avec une réalisation très propre et un gameplay intéressant, qui peine cependant à se démarquer de la série dont il s'inspire. A faire si vous avez déjà terminé tous les classiques du genre.

[h1]Verdict : 3,5/5 - Ce qui est bien, mais pas top.[/h1]

22669644.review:
I nearly didn't buy ChromaGun because I read in another review that the difficulty spiked and the game went from gentle puzzling to demanding serious dexterity. I'm glad I chose to try it anyway.  For context, let me explain that I am an average gamer in my early-fifties with serious sight issues, and yet I completed the game in around 10 hours with 100% achievements. The puzzles ranged from easy to mildly challenging. The basic mechanic of manipulating droids by changing their colour, or the colour of their surroundings, is a neat one. The devs have borrowed Portal's premise of a guy (or gal) going through test chambers. Critics might say this is unoriginal and I suppose they have a point, but at least it's better than the cheesy 'contestant in a deadly game show' format utilised by several of the other games in this genre. It also means Chromagun's  levels are bite-size - some of them take a few seconds to complete once you're figured the solution - so if you screw up it's no hardship to restart and try again.  This makes it a good game to boot up whether you have ten minutes to kill or wish to spend a few hours gaming.

To sum up, ChromaGun isn't an ambitious game. The graphics and sound are solid and unpretentious, it's slick and bug-free, and there's a welcome side serving of humour in the voice over. Recommend. 8/10

22638049.review:
Copy of the game provided by the developers

I have been playing ChromaGun for a couple of hours and I can tell this game is going to be loved by all those who like a puzzle game. There is a good amount of humor and the narrator voice is pure honey, you're going to enjoy listening to it even when it says how dumb you are for failing the puzzle for the 22nd time in a row.
Speaking of puzzles, they get challenging pretty quickly and some will test your planning skills as well as your reflexes. 

The game is about mixing the primary colors in order to get some droids to point A to point B, sometimes painting walls, others painting the drones themselves. Other times you'll have to make the drones suicide on electrified floor in order to be able to progress with the puzzle. As the game says: if you went to primary school you won't have any troubles understanding the game mechanics. 
Graphically and musically speaking, the game is average, nothing to write home about, but both get their job done. The music is very relaxing and helps the thinking a lot and the graphics could be better, sure, but could also be much worse.

Overall I agree with most of the reviews: this game is a solid puzzle game that you'll enjoy a lot, with a "portal" feeling to it but also it's own soul.

21312158.review:
NOTE: This game was given to me by the developer for review purposes. This did not influence my review in any way.

[h1]==========================================================
---------------------------------------OVERVIEW-------------------------------------
==========================================================[/h1]
ChromaGun is a puzzle game with first-person shooter mechanics. The concept of the game is simple: use your paint gun to paint walls and droids to open doors and escape each level. But, especially in later levels, some of the puzzles are quite devious. It will take a bit of brainpower and some nimble droid dodging to make your way to the end.

[h1]==========================================================
----------------------------------------QUALITY-------------------------------------
==========================================================[/h1]
Graphics - The graphics are large and colourful. Droids are suitably mechanical spheres hovering on small booster rockets, and it's easy to see which ones are dangerous and which are not from a quick glance. Given that the main idea behind the game is colour matching, it's obviously important for you to be able to quickly see the difference between the different coloured wall panels and droids. For the most part, the game handles this well, although in a couple of cases a droid in shadow was actually not the colour I first thought.

Graphics settings are pretty limited, but appropriate: a pre-game dialog box allows you to choose graphic detail (low, medium, high) and resolution, as well as whether you want windowed mode or full screen.

Sound - Sound is mostly pretty minimal. The game has some fairly forgettable background music, and the *pew,pew* and *bzzt* sounds of your chromagun and electric tiles, respectively, are okay, but nothing special. The voiceover of your supervisor / tormentor is very well done indeed.

Gameplay - In typical puzzle game style, ChromaGun divides its offering into a large number of small levels, grouped into different areas. The areas themselves are fairly unimportant, though, as each level has much the same theme -- there are no different worlds or anything like that -- so it's really just a long list of levels to get through. You start the game as a contractor for ChromaTech, at the office to test the new ChromaGun, a three-colour paint gun capable of colouring certain wall tiles and some droids. Droids of a particular colour are attracted to wall tiles of that colour, you're told in the first level, and from that point on the game has you using your gun to colour wall tiles and droids in your efforts to make it through the testing facility. Switches are introduced early on, and later levels include much harder obstacles, such as droids that can kill you, electrified floor tiles, and automated wall cleaners that remove your paint within seconds of spraying it on.

It's important for a puzzle game that the player is able to quickly grasp the mechanics and interface, and be able to focus on solving the puzzles. ChromaGun does this well, with a very shallow learning curve in the first two areas leading into some downright tricky later levels in the later areas. I still haven't managed to finish the game: one particular level in area five is doing my head in at the moment!

[h1]==========================================================
-------------------------------------PROS & CONS------------------------------------
==========================================================[/h1]
Pros:
+ Clean, colourful graphics suit the game well.
+ Voice over and associated humour is very well done. I've laughed out loud a few times while playing.
+ shallow learning curve makes sure you grasp the simplest ideas well before increasing complexity.
+ Steam achievements will keep you coming back for one more try, even when your rage meter is approaching the redline.

Cons:
- The primary mechanic is simple, and the game doesn't offer a whole lot more than that. In the later levels it can get a bit repetitive.

[h1]==========================================================
--------------------------------------CONCLUSION-----------------------------------
==========================================================[/h1]
ChromaGun is a well-made puzzle game with minor FPS components. It has high production values and a core mechanic that works, so it sticks to it.

[h1]7/10[/h1]

21251103.review:
Chromagun is billed as a first-person action puzzle game, although it starts off focusing mostly on the puzzle aspect and then picks up the pace later on. If you're after a thoughtful, no-pressure game then you'll struggle later on where speed is important.

It's inspired by Portal, with a similar look and narration, but the puzzle mechanic is totally different. Here, it's about painting walls and droids different colours with your paint gun. Droids get pulled towards any surface that's the same colour as them, so you use that fact to move them around the level and position them on pressure pads that open doors. 

To add some action, some droids are deadly to the touch and will chase you around the level if there's no coloured surface to pull them in. 

Some gameplay from chapter 2, post-tutorial:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DKz5va-z3DM

The paint-mixing idea is a great basis for setting puzzles, but it feels like they could have done more than just using it to get droids to cling to walls. Particularly because (based on what I've played so far, 3/4 of the way through the game) this is a 3D game that never really uses the third dimension in your puzzle solving.

Like all decent puzzle games, the game intelligently drip-feeds in new elements and teaches you their use, either through direct explanation or letting you discover it for yourself. Chapter 1 is a tutorial with one colour in your gun, Chapter 2 gives you the full three-colour gun and teaches you the art of mixing, while chapter 3 adds killer floor tiles that destroy droids, sometimes to your advantage. Chapter 4 adds walls that remove your paint after a short time. And so on, up to Chapter 8.

But this is a game with a story, and Chapter 4 ends on an action-packed climax ready for an atmospheric Chapter 5. At this point you wonder if the game up to this point was one long tutorial! Beyond this, the puzzles require faster thinking, faster timing and all-round more speed to proceed.

A few puzzles are inelegantly designed, ones that makes you wonder if you found an unintended shortcut or whether the rooms needed a second draft.

For instance, level 4.5 was first one where I was stumped for a while - the solution turned out to be mentally putting together stuff I'd done before, but it also required getting a droid to pass a certain point at a certain time that was annoyingly fiddly - I had already figured things out but spent ages running in circles to get it just right. I couldn't work out if it was me or the game at fault.

But all the puzzles are contained enough to be manageable. It rarely puts a second difficult puzzle after a first within a level (which might mean if you die on the second you'd have to plod all the way through the first again).

So I've been enjoying this, with reservations. I found the early stuff a bit gentle and I rattled through a lot of the game before hitting the real challenge, but it always changed things up before becoming boring. I enjoy the moments of panic and quick-thinking, and solving a puzzle is satisfying. But some of the timing later on is too tight to be fun and gets frustrating. But never mouse-breakingly so!

* [url=https://youtube.com/user/randomiseuser]More gaming videos by Randomise User[/url]

39591183.review:
There's some well-designed puzzles and the core colour mechanic works just fine, but I got incredibly tired of several things while playing this game. First and foremost, just how shameless a Portal ripoff it is. (Consider that there's an achievement for finding a hidden cake called "Not A Lie") Frankly, it's a little bit galling that this game has been as commercially successful as it has been, but I'm sure Valve have too many billion dollars to care. Second, the gags just don't land. They draw a smirk at best and are repeated over and over and over and over again (no, I didn't step on the deadly electrified maintenance tiles because I forgot they'd kill me, thank you very much). Third, the voiceover guy really can't act. His voice is pleasing enough, but he's not a very good actor.

5.5/10. The only reason I have as many hours as I do is because this game launched with a speedrunning contest and I tried my hand at that.
